questions.text: A 36-year-old female patient comes with complaints of menorrhagia for the past 3 months. The duration and regularity of her menstrual cycles are normal. Non-hormonal management has been tried without success. What is the most appropriate next step?

72-year-old woman presents with complete uterine prolapse (procidentia) and urinary incontinence. She is sexually inactive, has multiple comorbidities, and wants a short operative time. What is the best management?

options.label: B
options.text: Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair

questions.text: During post-op rounds, you note one of the patients has developed fever and flank pain. The nurses inform you that her abdominal drain outputs have been consistently high. Which of the following procedures has the highest incidence of the complication suspected here?

A 19-year-old girl was brought by her mother to the outpatient department with primary amenorrhea. She had normal breast development and pubic hair. On examination, the vagina was blind-ending and the uterus was not palpable. What is the most probable diagnosis?

A 32-year-old woman presents with 2 years of primary infertility. Her cycles are regular and she has no history of dysmenorrhea or dyspareunia. She underwent an HSG which showed bilateral tubal patency. Her husband’s semen analysis is normal. Transvaginal ultrasound shows a normal uterus with an antral follicle count (AFC) of 5. Day 3 labs show: • FSH: 14 IU/L • LH: 5 IU/L • AMH: 0.6 ng/mL What is the most likely cause of infertility?

A woman undergoes infertility treatment and her Usg shows follicles bigger than 18 mm and serum E2 level is 3500 pg/ml Which of the following reduces the risk of OHSS without compromising pregnancy rates in high-risk women?

options.label: A
options.text: Dual trigger with hCG and GnRH agonist

options.label: B
options.text: Coasting until estradiol levels fall, followed by hCG trigger

options.label: C
options.text: GnRH agonist trigger in antagonist cycles with frozen embryo transfer

options.label: D
options.text: Immediate oocyte retrieval when follicles reach 10 mm

questions.correct_answer: C. GnRH agonist trigger in antagonist cycles with frozen embryo transfer

questions.text: A 27 year old girl presents with primary amenorrhea. On examination breasts were found to be poorly developed, vagina was present. Ultrasound revealed normal uterus but gonads weren’t detected. Further evaluation done showed 46XY karyotype. The most probable diagnosis?

28-year-old woman presents with thin, off-white, malodorous vaginal discharge for 1 week. She denies itching or dyspareunia. On speculum exam, the vaginal walls are mildly erythematous with homogenous discharge. Wet mount shows clue cells, pH of 5.5, and a positive whiff test. She has no urinary symptoms and is currently 9 weeks pregnant. She was treated for asymptomatic BV in her last pregnancy and delivered preterm at 32 weeks. What is the most appropriate next step?

options.label: C
options.text: Start oral metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days

questions.correct_answer: C. Start oral metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days

questions.text: 56-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with moderate to severe vasomotor symptoms and dyspareunia affecting her quality of life. She is 6 years postmenopausal and has an intact uterus. Her past medical history includes deep vein thrombosis (DVT) 4 years ago, for which she completed anticoagulation. She has a BMI of 29, is normotensive, and her recent mammogram and pelvic ultrasound are normal. She is seeking treatment for symptom relief. What is the most appropriate management?

options.label: C
options.text: Vaginal estrogen cream with SSRI for vasomotor symptoms

options.label: D
options.text: Tibolone therapy for vasomotor and genitourinary symptoms

questions.correct_answer: C. Vaginal estrogen cream with SSRI for vasomotor symptoms

questions.text: A teenage girl presented with complaints of excessive growth of coarse hair on her jawline and upper lip. Which of the following is the most common cause for this condition?

An elderly woman who was found to have an ovarian mass underwent staging laparotomy. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of HPE finding shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?

A 62-year-old woman presents with painless vaginal bleeding for the past 3 days. She reached menopause 10 years ago and is not on hormone replacement therapy. She has no significant medical history, and her last Pap smear (1 year ago) was normal. On speculum examination, there is blood in the vagina but no obvious cervical or vaginal lesion. Transvaginal ultrasound reveals an endometrial thickness of 6 mm. What is the next best step in the evaluation of this patient?

A 42-year-old woman presents with complaints of heavy, prolonged menstrual bleeding for the past 6 months. She is hemodynamically stable and not anemic. Pelvic exam is normal. Transvaginal ultrasound shows a normal-sized uterus with no fibroids, and endometrial thickness is 6 mm. She desires uterine preservation, is not planning future pregnancy, and is not keen on surgery. She has no contraindications to hormonal therapy. Which of the following is the most effective management?
The CT of a patient with cervical carcinoma revealed a lesion of 6 cm, extending to the upper part of the vagina and parametrium. What Is the stage of the disease?
A 45-year-old woman presented with menorrhagia. A hysterectomy was performed, and the specimen is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
